case_name: Sardar Gian Singh v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Sardar Gian Singh was recruited in 1927 as a Naib Tehsildar in the Revenue department of the Province of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Gian Singh-hereinafter Called the appellant- was recruited in 1927 as a Naib Tehsildar in the Revenue department of the Province of Punjab. He was companyfirmed in that rank in 1939.

facts.text: Sardar Gian Singh was confirmed in the rank of Naib Tehsildar in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: He was companyfirmed in that rank in 1939. In 1946, he was promoted to the rank of officiating Tehsildar and was posted as Tehsildar at Hansi in the district of Hissar on September 22, 1947,

facts.text: Sardar Gian Singh was promoted to the rank of officiating Tehsildar in 1946 and posted as Tehsildar at Hansi on September 22, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In 1946, he was promoted to the rank of officiating Tehsildar and was posted as Tehsildar at Hansi in the district of Hissar on September 22, 1947, and since then he held the post of Tehsildar at diverse places.

facts.text: On August 20, 1952, the appellant was served with a charge sheet by the Financial Commissioner, Punjab containing eleven heads of charges of misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20 , 1952, the appellant was served with a charge sheet by the Financial Commissioner, Punjab companytaining eleven heads of charges of, misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties companymitted by him.

facts.text: The Deputy Commissioner, Hissar was appointed to hold a departmental enquiry into the charges against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Deputy Commissioner, Hissar was appointed to hold a departmental enquiry into those charges. On August 28, 1953, the appellant was served with a numberice to show cause why on the findings recorded by the enquiry officer,

facts.text: On August 28, 1953, the appellant was served with a notice to show cause why he should not be dismissed from service based on the enquiry findings.

anchor.surface_text: On August 28, 1953, the appellant was served with a numberice to show cause why on the findings recorded by the enquiry officer, he should number be dismissed from service. The appellant submitted hi, explanation.

facts.text: The Financial Commissioner by order dated October 26, 1953 ordered that the appellant be dismissed from service.

anchor.surface_text: The Financial Commissioner by order dated October 26, 1953 ordered that the appellant be dismissed from service. An appeal preferred against that order was dismissed and application to the Government of Punjab to revise the order of the appellate authority also proved infructuous.

facts.text: An appeal against the dismissal order was dismissed and a revision application to the Government of Punjab proved infructuous.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal preferred against that order was dismissed and application to the Government of Punjab to revise the order of the appellate authority also proved infructuous. The appellant then presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Punjab

facts.text: The appellant filed a petition under Article 226 of the Constitution in the Punjab High Court seeking to quash the dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then presented a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Punjab for an order quashing the order of dismissal company- tending inter alia that  a  reasonable opportunity was number given to the appellant

facts.text: Bishan Narain J. rejected the plea of no reasonable opportunity but held the Financial Commissioner incompetent to dismiss due to amendment of Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937.

anchor.surface_text: Bishan Narain, J., who heard the petition rejected the first plea, but in the view of the learned Judge, the Financial Commissioner ceased to have any power to make rules regulating the appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars because of the amendment of the Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887 by the Government of India  Adaptation of Indian Laws  Order, 1937

facts.text: In Letters Patent Appeal No. 82 of 1957, Division Bench of Punjab High Court reversed Bishan Narain J. and dismissed the petition on September 3, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 3, 1958, of the Punjab High Court in Letters Patent Appeal No. 82 of 1957.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court with certificate under Article 133.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed to this Court against the order of the High Court with certificates of fitness under Art. 133 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Rules for appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars were framed in 1932 by Financial Commissioner under s.9 and s.28 of Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 9 read with s. 28 of the Act, rules were framed in 1932 by the Financial Commissioner, Punjab, and authority to appoint Tehsildars and to remove them from service was, by these rules, companyferred upon the Financial Commissioner.

facts.text: Section 9 of Punjab Land Revenue Act amended by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, deleting power of Financial Commissioner to make rules for appointment and dismissal.

anchor.surface_text: After the enactment of the Government of India Act, 1935, s. 9 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act was amended by the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, and the power of the Financial Commissioner to make rules under s. 9 was abrogated by the deletion of the words in that section following the word appointed.

facts.text: Petitioner claimed no reasonable opportunity was given to rebut allegations.

anchor.surface_text: for an order quashing the order of dismissal company- tending inter alia that  a  reasonable opportunity was number given to the appellant either before the enquiry officer or before the Financial Commissioner to rebut the allegations companytained in the charge sheet,

facts.text: Petitioner claimed Financial Commissioner was incompetent to pass dismissal order.

anchor.surface_text: and  b  that the Financial Commissioner was incompetent to pass the order of dismissal.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Tehsildari Rules 1932 continued in force and Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss.

anchor.surface_text: the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was number unauthorised.

facts.text: Plea that Civil Services Rules 1941 superseded Tehsildari Rules not raised in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: But the plea that fresh rules were framed in 1941 in supersession of the Punjab Tesbsildari Rules, 1932 was number advanced in the High Court.

facts.text: Raghubar Dayal J dissented, holding dismissal illegal as Financial Commissioner not competent under Civil Services Rules.

anchor.surface_text: I am therefore of opinion that the dismissal of the appellant by the Financial Commissioner is illegal. I would therefore allow the appeal with companyts, set aside the order under appeal and restore the order of the learned Single Judge, dated April 4, 1957.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with companyts.

Bishan Narain, J., who heard the petition rejected the first plea, but in the view of the learned Judge, the Financial Commissioner ceased to have any power to make rules regulating the appointment and dismissal of Tehsildars because of the amendment of the Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887 by the Government of India  Adaptation of Indian Laws  Order, 1937

issues.text: Whether the Tehsildari Rules framed in 1932 continued in force after the amendment of the Punjab Land Revenue Act by the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 by virtue of cls. 9 and 10 thereof

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 9 read with s. 28 of the Act, rules were framed in 1932 by the Financial Commissioner, Punjab, and authority to appoint Tehsildars and to remove them from service was, by these rules, conferred upon the Financial Commissioner. After the enactment of the Government of India Act, 1935, s. 9 of the Punjab Land Revenue Act was amended by the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, and the power of the Financial Commissioner to make rules under s. 9 was abrogated by the deletion of the words in that section following the word appointed.

arguments.court_reasoning: Tehsildari Rules in operation conferred power

holdings.text: The Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules by virtue of clause 9 of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 9 which provided The provisions of this order which adapt or modify Indian laws so as to alter the manner in which, the authority by which, or the law under or in accordance with which, any powers are exercisable, shall not render invalid any notification, order, commitment, attachment,, bye-law, rule or regulation duly made or issued, or anything duly done, before the commencement of this order Notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules, the Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 9 expressly provides that adaptations do not render prior rules invalid; rules duly made before commencement continue valid.

holdings.text: The authority of the Financial Commissioner under the Tehsildari Rules continued to be vested and exercisable by virtue of clause 10 of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 until other provision made.

anchor.surface_text: And by cl. 10 which provided Save as provided by this order, all powers which under any law in force in British India, or in any part of British India, were immediately before the commencement of part III of the Government of India Act, 1935 vested in, or exercisable by, any person or authority shall continue to be so vested or exercisable until other provision is made by some legislature or authority empowered to regulate the matter in question. The authority of the Financial Commissioner under the rules which remained in force by virtue of cl. 9 was exercisable except as provided by the Adaptation of Indian Laws order, 1937.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clause 10 saves pre-existing powers until replaced; combined with cl.9, sustains FC's authority under rules.

holdings.text: The conditions of service of civil servants continued unaltered after Government of India Act 1935 by virtue of cl.15(2) Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936 saved by cl.12(d) Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937.

anchor.surface_text: By el. 15 2  it was provided Until other provision is made under the new Act, the conditions of service applicable to any person ... shall be the same as were applicable ... immediately before the commencement of Part III of the new Act. By el. 12 d  of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 ... No repeal ... shall affect the operation of sub-paragraph  2  of paragraph fifteen ... By the combined operation of cl. 15 2  of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order, 1936 and the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, the conditions of service applicable to civil servants continued to remain unaltered, until other provisions were made under the Government of India Act, 1935.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transitory provisions preserve pre-existing conditions until new rules made; saved from repeal.

holdings.text: Section 241(2) Government of India Act 1935 was subject to cl.15(2) Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936 until other provisions made.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 241  2  of the Government of India Act, 1935, the conditions of service, in the case of persons serving in connection with the affairs of a Province, were to be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Governor ... But this provision was, till other- provisions were made, subject to cl. 15  2  of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order, 1936.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.241 prospective but transitory cl.15(2) defers change in conditions until new provision.

holdings.text: Clause 7 of Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937 does not apply where authority like Financial Commissioner continues to exist, only powers adjusted.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 7 of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order ... applies only to those cases where an authority competent ... ceased to exist and a corresponding new authority was constituted ... The clause did not apply where only the powers of an authority were vested in another authority, the former authority not otherwise ceasing to function.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cl.7 limited to cases of authority ceasing existence; FC office continued.

holdings.text: The record does not support that Punjab Tehsildari Rules were not in operation at date of dismissal; Financial Commissioner invested with power to dismiss Tehsildar.

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, we are of the view that the record does not support the contention that the Punjab Tehsildari Rules were not in operation at the date of dismissal. There is also nothing to show that the Financial Commissioner was not invested at the material time with the power to dismiss a Tehsildar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plea of supersession by 1941 PCS Rules not raised below, no notifications produced; r.1.4 excludes via special provision; record indicates rules operational.

holdings.text: The order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was not unauthorised.

anchor.surface_text: the condition of service of civil servants having remained unaltered even after the Government of India Act, 1935 was brought into operation by virtue of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936, and the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order having made express provision saving the rules as well as the authority granted under the rules to the Financial Commissioner, the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was not unauthorised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of saving clauses, transitory provisions, and record confirms FC authority.

anchor.surface_text: observations in Watson v. Winch 1 . The Revenue Act, after amendment, did number provide about the appointment of Tehsildars and Naib Tehsildars. This must have been in view of the statutory provision existing for the purpose in sub- s. 1 of s. 241 of the Act whose relevant portion is Except as expressly provided by this Act, appointments to the civil services of, and civil posts under, the Crown in India, shall, after the companymencement of Part III of this Act, be made- x x x x x  b  in the case of services of province, and posts in companynection with the affairs of a provinces by the Governor or such person as he may direct It is to be numbericed that the modifications made by the Adaptation Order to ss. 7 and 8 deleted the provisions empowering the State Government to remove the officers it companyld appoint under the provisions of those sections.

precedents.cited_proposition: consequence of repeal is that power deemed never existed and rules framed without jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: In Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta 1  this Court had to companysider whether the Chief Justice of the Calcutta High Court had power to dismiss an employee of the High Court. In this companynection, it was number disputed that the Chief Justice was the authority for appointing the appellant. But it was companytended that he had number the power to dismiss. The companytention was that the appellant was a public servant governed by the Civil Services  Classifica- tion, Control and Appeal  Rules of 1930, as amended from time to time and that those rules companytinued to apply even after the Government of India Act, 1935, and later when the Constitution of India came into force. It was number disputed that ,dismissal was a matter falling within companydition of service of a public servant as held by the Privy, Council in North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand 2 , and that the power of making rules relating to the companyditions of service of staff of the High Court was vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court under s. 242 4  taken with s. 241 of the Act and also under Art. 229 2 , of the companystitution.

precedents.case_name: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: power of appointment carries with it the power of dismissal
precedents.cited_holding: power of appointment was throughout understood as vesting... the complete administrative and disciplinary control over its staff, including the power of dismissal

precedents.citation: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand 2

anchor.surface_text: It was number disputed that ,dismissal was a matter falling within companydition of service of a public servant as held by the Privy, Council in North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand 2 , and that the power of making rules relating to the companyditions of service of staff of the High Court was vested in the Chief Justice of the High Court under s. 242 4  taken with s. 241 of the Act and also under Art. 229 2 , of the companystitution. It was however companytended that the Chief Justice of the High Court had number framed any such rules and that therefore, by virtue of s. 276 of the Act and Art. 313 of the companystitution, the Civil Services Rules companytinued to apply to the appellant.

precedents.case_name: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand
precedents.cited_proposition: dismissal was a matter falling within condition of service of a public servant

precedents.citation: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta 1

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection I may quote the very apposite observations in Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta  1  at page 290 The companytinued application of the Civil Services Rules without such adaptation would result in the anomalous position, that although the 1935 Act specifically vests in the Chief Justice the power of appointment and of framing rules regulating companyditions, of service including the power of dismissal and hence thereby indicates the Chief Justice as the authority having the power to exercise disciplinary companytrol, he has numbersuch disci- plinary companytrol merely because he did number choose to make any fresh rules and was companytent with the companytinued application of the old rules.

precedents.case_name: Pradyat Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: continued application of old rules without adaptation leads to anomaly where vesting power is ignored
precedents.cited_holding: The continued application of the Civil Services Rules without such adaptation would result in the anomalous position...

anchor.surface_text: By cl. 9 which provided The provisions of this order which adapt or modify Indian laws so as to alter the manner in which, the authority by which, or the law under or in accordance with which, any powers are exercisable, shall not render invalid any notification, order, commitment, attachment,, bye-law, rule or regulation duly made or issued, or anything duly done, before the commencement of this order Notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules, the Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: And by cl. 10 which provided Save as provided by this order, all powers which under any law in force in British India, or in any part of British India, were immediately before the commencement of part III of the Government of India Act, 1935 vested in, or exercisable by, any person or authority shall continue to be so vested or exercisable until other provision is made by some legislature or authority empowered to regulate the matter in question. The authority of the Financial Commissioner under the rules which remained in force by virtue of cl. 9 was exercisable except as provided by the Adaptation of Indian Laws order, 1937.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

By el. 15 2  it was provided Until other provision is made under the new Act, the conditions of service applicable to any person ... shall be the same as were applicable ... immediately before the commencement of Part III of the new Act. By el. 12 d  of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937 ... No repeal ... shall affect the operation of sub-paragraph  2  of paragraph fifteen ... By the combined operation of cl. 15 2  of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order, 1936 and the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order, 1937, the conditions of service applicable to civil servants continued to remain unaltered, until other provisions were made under the Government of India Act, 1935.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: By s. 241  2  of the Government of India Act, 1935, the conditions of service, in the case of persons serving in connection with the affairs of a Province, were to be such as may be prescribed by rules made by the Governor ... But this provision was, till other- provisions were made, subject to cl. 15  2  of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order, 1936.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 7 of the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order ... applies only to those cases where an authority competent ... ceased to exist and a corresponding new authority was constituted ... The clause did not apply where only the powers of an authority were vested in another authority, the former authority not otherwise ceasing to function.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding affirms rules in operation and FC power to dismiss despite amendment deleting rule-making power
FC power to dismiss (h6) grounds validation of dismissal order (h7) [REPAIRED: grounds->supports]

anchor.surface_text: On the whole, we are of the view that the record does not support the contention that the Punjab Tehsildari Rules were not in operation at the date of dismissal. There is also nothing to show that the Financial Commissioner was not invested at the material time with the power to dismiss a Tehsildar.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.

edges.explanation: Holding validates dismissal order as authorised, undercutting impact of power deletion in c4

anchor.surface_text: the condition of service of civil servants having remained unaltered even after the Government of India Act, 1935 was brought into operation by virtue of the Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936, and the Adaptation of Indian Laws Order having made express provision saving the rules as well as the authority granted under the rules to the Financial Commissioner, the order of the Financial Commissioner dismissing the appellant from service was not unauthorised.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed with costs.
